questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is brought to the pediatric clinic by concerned parents due to a noticeable, well-defined swelling on the right side of the head, which was not present at birth but developed a few hours after delivery. The baby was delivered vaginally with the assistance of vacuum extraction due to prolonged labor. The swelling does not cross suture lines and is non-tender on palpation. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable, and the baby appears to be feeding well and is otherwise healthy. Given the clinical presentation and the history of vacuum-assisted delivery, which of the following best describes the location of bleeding in cephalhematoma, as observed in this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Between Fifth Layer and Skull

 

Option D:

 

  • Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is confined to one cranial bone.

  • It occurs between the outer layer of the cranial bone and the periosteum, which is the dense layer of vascular connective tissue enveloping the bones except at the surfaces of the joints.

 

 

  • The characteristic presentation includes a well-defined swelling that does not cross cranial suture lines, as the periosteum is tightly adhered to the bone at the sutures.

  • Cephalhematomas are often associated with birth trauma, which can occur with the use of assistive devices such as vacuum extractors during delivery.

  • Unlike other types of head swellings in newborns, such as caput succedaneum, cephalhematomas develop a few hours to days after birth and are not present at birth. This condition is generally self-limiting, with the blood gradually being reabsorbed over weeks to months.

 

Cephalhematoma blood collects beneath the fifth layer of scalp (pericranium). It is localised and takes the shape of the related bone and doesnâ€™t cross sutures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: First layer of scalp is provided with numerous sebaceous glands and is common site of sebaceous cysts.

 

Option B: Second layer of scalp is made of dense connective tissue to which the walls of blood vessels are adhered and if cut results in profuse bleeding.

 

Option C: Third layer of scalp is the aponeurotic layer with occipitofrontalis muscle, the fibres of gale aponeurotica if cut transversely will result in gaping of wounds. The fourth layer is made of loose connective tissue and is called dangerous layer of scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cephalohematoma is a condition where bleeding occurs underneath the skin, over one or several cranial bones, in newborns. This hematoma is specifically found between the periosteum (the outer covering of the bone) and the skull bone itself. The periosteum can be considered as part of the "fifth layer" when enumerating the scalp layers, which include: Skin, Connective tissue, Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica), Loose connective tissue and Periosteum (Pericranium).

  • Cephalohematoma is confined by the sutures of the skull because the periosteum is tightly adhered to the bone at the sutures. This means the bleeding does not cross suture lines, distinguishing cephalohematomas from other types of swelling or bleeding, such as caput succedaneum, which can cross suture lines.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 68

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of double vision and difficulty navigating stairs, particularly when looking down. She also reports discomfort when trying to read for prolonged periods. On examination, she demonstrates an inability to move her right eye downward and laterally. The rest of the neurological examination, including other cranial nerve functions, is normal. Based on the specific deficit in eye movement, which cranial nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV

 

Option B:

 

  • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for downward and lateral movement of the eyeball.

  • Injury or dysfunction of the trochlear nerve leads to weakness of the superior oblique muscle, resulting in difficulty with eye movements, particularly in looking downward and laterally.

 

 

  • This can manifest clinically as vertical diplopia (double vision), which becomes more pronounced when the patient attempts to look down, such as when going downstairs or reading.

  • The inability to properly intort and depress the eye when in an adducted position (looking towards the nose) is characteristic of trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: III Nerve innervates  levator palpebrae superioris, superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus and inferior oblique.

 

Option C: VI nerve innervates Lateral rectus muscle.  This is not the answer since she is not only having the difficulty in looking down but also laterally.

 

Option D: Ophthalmic division of V nerve provides sensory innervation to eyeball. And has no motor involvement in movements of the eye ball.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the smallest and the only cranial nerve that exits dorsally from the brainstem. It innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for downward and outward movement (depression and abduction) of the eyeball.

  • When the superior oblique muscle is paralyzed due to dysfunction of the trochlear nerve, the affected individual may experience difficulty with the following eye movements:

  1. Depression (Looking Down): The superior oblique muscle primarily facilitates the downward movement of the eye, particularly when the eye is adducted (turned towards the nose). Paralysis of this muscle impairs the ability to look downward, which is especially noticeable when the individual tries to look down, such as while reading or descending stairs.

  2. Abduction: While the primary function of the superior oblique is to depress the eye, it also contributes to abduction when the eye is in a partially adducted position. Therefore, paralysis can also affect the ability to look outward, but this is less pronounced compared to its effect on depression.

 

The typical clinical manifestation of trochlear nerve palsy includes vertical diplopia (double vision), where the patient sees two images that are vertically aligned, particularly when looking down or when tilting the head towards the shoulder opposite to the affected eye. This is because the unaffected eye moves down normally, but the eye with the paralyzed superior oblique muscle lags behind, leading to misalignment of the visual axes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 365

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of progressive difficulty swallowing solid foods and a sensation of food sticking in his throat. He also reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially when lying down, but denies any weight loss, heartburn, or respiratory symptoms. Barium swallow study shows a posterior protrusion in the pharyngoesophageal region, suggesting the presence of Zenker’s diverticulum. Given the location and presentation of the patient's symptoms, which anatomical area associated with the development of Zenker's diverticulum is most relevant to this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricopharyngeus

 

Option C:

 

  • Killian's dehiscence refers to a specific area of potential weakness in the pharyngeal wall, located in the posterior aspect of the pharynx at the transition between the pharynx and esophagus.

 

 

 

  • This area is particularly relevant in the context of Zenker's diverticulum, which is a type of pharyngeal pouch that can herniate through this weak spot.
  • Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum that arises in Killian's dehiscence, an area of potential weakness between the oblique fibers of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle (thyropharyngeus) and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle.
  • This area is part of the pharyngoesophageal junction, located just above the upper esophageal sphincter. The cricopharyngeus muscle, which is part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • Increased intraluminal pressure during swallowing, due to dysfunction or incoordination of the cricopharyngeus muscle, leads to herniation of the mucosal layer through Killian's dehiscence, forming the diverticulum.
  • The nasopharynx and oropharynx are higher up in the pharyngeal anatomy and not directly involved in the formation of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • The thyropharyngeus muscle contributes to the boundary of Killian's dehiscence but is not the primary site associated with the diverticulum formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The nasopharynx is the upper part of the pharynx, lying behind the nose and above the soft palate. Killian's dehiscence is not located in the nasopharynx; it is found much lower, near the transition from the pharynx to the esophagus.

 

Option B: The oropharynx lies below the nasopharynx and extends from the soft palate to the upper edge of the epiglottis. While the oropharynx is involved in swallowing, Killian's dehiscence is not located here but rather in the lower pharyngeal region.

 

Option D: The thyropharyngeus is another part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, positioned superior to the cricopharyngeus muscle. While it contributes to the structure of the pharyngeal wall, Killian's dehiscence is specifically related to the area near the cricopharyngeus muscle rather than the thyropharyngeus muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cricopharyngeus muscle is part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle and acts as the upper esophageal sphincter.
  • Killian's dehiscence is located in the area where the muscle fibers of the cricopharyngeus part slightly, creating a potential area of weakness between the thyropharyngeus portion of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor and the cricopharyngeus muscle itself.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 224.

questions.text: The First Branch of External Carotid Artery
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ascending Pharyngeal Artery

 

Option A:

 

The ascending pharyngeal artery is the first branch of the external carotid artery. (Do not confuse it with superior thyroid artery as some texts mention that superior thyroid artery is the first bench but in detailed and recent studies it has been updated to ascending pharyngeal artery as the first branch.)

 

It is a small but significant vessel that arises from the medial surface of the external carotid artery very close to its origin from the common carotid bifurcation.

 

It is the smallest branch but also the first and most consistent branch of the external carotid artery.

 

It is the only medial branch of ECA as well
 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Facial artery arises just above the tip of the greater cornu of hyoid bone in the carotid triangle.

 

Option C: Superior thyroid artery often arises from the external carotid artery near its origin, but it may also originate from the common carotid bifurcation in many cases. It is not consistently the first branch.

 

Option D: Lingual artery arises just opposite the tip of greater cornu of hyoid bone and its course is divided into 3 parts by hyoglossus muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ascending pharyngeal artery is the first branch of the external carotid artery and is its only medial branch.

 

It is a long, slender vessel that runs superiorly along the lateral wall of the pharynx to the base of the skull.

 

The ascending pharyngeal artery supplies:

  • The pharynx
  • Middle ear
  • Meninges
  • Prevertebral muscles
  • Parts of the soft palate

 

While the superior thyroid artery is often described as the first branch in some texts, more detailed anatomical studies indicate that the ascending pharyngeal artery typically originates first from the external carotid artery.

 

Ref: Recent anatomical studies and advanced imaging research on the external carotid arterial system

questions.text: All the following nerves innervate the pointed structure except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) XII

 

Option D:

 

  • The pointed structure is soft palate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IX, X, XI nerve contributes to the pharyngeal plexus which supplies the soft palate. Vagus is motor

 

Option B. All muscles of soft palate are innervated by pharyngeal plexus except tensor veli palatini which is innervated by trunk of mandibular nerve

 

Option C. IX nerve conveys the sensations from the soft palate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the muscles of tongue except palatoglossus

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 131

questions.text: All will occur in damage to Oculomotor Nerve except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral and Upward Deviation

 

Option A: Oculomotor nerve injury will cause the eyeball to turn down and out due to contraction of superior oblique innervated by trochlear nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The accommodation reflex involves changes in the lens of the eye to focus on near objects, and the oculomotor nerve provides the parasympathetic innervation necessary for this process. Damage to the oculomotor nerve would impair the ability to constrict the pupil and change the shape of the lens for near vision, leading to loss of accommodation.

 

Option C: The parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve innervate the sphincter pupillae muscle, which constricts the pupil. Damage to the oculomotor nerve can lead to a lack of parasympathetic input, resulting in a dilated pupil (mydriasis) due to unopposed sympathetic activity.

 

Option D: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid. Damage to this nerve would result in ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, due to paralysis of the levator muscle. Paralysis of levatorpalapabrae superioris results in ptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Damage to the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) can lead to several ocular deficits, as this nerve innervates the majority of the extraocular muscles, the levator palpebrae superioris muscle (which elevates the upper eyelid) and provides parasympathetic innervation to the pupil and lens.

  • In oculomotor nerve palsy, the eye tends to deviate "down and out," not lateral and upward. This is due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the abducens nerve, CN VI) and superior oblique (innervated by the trochlear nerve, CN IV) muscles. The lateral rectus muscle abducts the eye, and the superior oblique muscle helps in intorsion and depression of the eye when it is in an abducted position. Therefore, damage to the oculomotor nerve typically results in the eye looking downward and outward, not lateral and upward.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 256

questions.text: Trigeminal Nerve supplies all of the following muscles except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Levatorveli Palatine

 

Option C:

 

  • Levator Veli Palatine: Muscle of Soft Palate, passes through sinus of Morgagni and its contraction elevates soft palate.

 

 

  • All muscles of soft palate are innervated by pharyngeal plexus except Tensor veli palatine

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tensor tympani-muscle of middle ear, derivative of first pharyngeal arch innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve. The tensor tympani muscle, which dampens sounds, such as those produced by chewing, is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (V3).

 

Option B: Tensor veli palatini tendon expands to form palatine aponeurosis, it's also called dilator tubae muscle and is innervated by trunk of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve. The tensor veli palatini muscle, which helps open the Eustachian tube during swallowing and yawning, is also innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (V3).

 

Option D: Anterior belly of digastric- innervated by nerve to mylohyoid, a branch of inferior alveolar nerve that arises from mandibular division of trigeminal nerve. The anterior belly of the digastric muscle, which aids in depressing the mandible, is innervated by the mylohyoid nerve, a branch of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (V3).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator veli palatini muscle, responsible for elevating the soft palate during swallowing and speaking, is not innervated by the trigeminal nerve. Instead, it is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions mainly from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 109

questions.text: Incorrect statement about the Layer of Deep Cervical Fascia pointed out in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Forms Sphenomandibular Ligament

 

Option B: The pointed structure is an investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It splits to enclose sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles; both are innervated by spinal accessory nerve.

 

Option C: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia forms the roof of anterior and posterior triangle. The prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia forms the floor of posterior triangle.

 

Option D: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia splits to enclose submandibular and parotid salivary glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: The deep lamellar that splits to enclose the parotid gland thickens to form the stylomandibular ligament which separates the parotid gland from submandibular gland.

  • Sphenomandibular ligament is remnant of meckelâ€™s cartilage.
     

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 176

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not paralysed in the clinical condition shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levator palpebrae superioris

 

Option D:

 

  • The given image-Bellâ€™s Palsy-Facial nerve palsy.

  • Bell's palsy is a condition characterized by sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles. This condition results in a drooping appearance on one side of the face, which might resemble a stroke. The exact cause of Bell's palsy is unknown, but it's often associated with viral infections that lead to inflammation of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which controls the muscles of facial expression.

  • Symptoms of Bell's palsy can vary from mild weakness to total paralysis and typically affect only one side of the face. Common symptoms include:

    • Sudden weakness or paralysis on one side of the face, making it difficult to smile or close the eye on that side

    • Drooping of the mouth or eyelid

    • Loss of facial expression

    • Increased sensitivity to sound on the affected side

    • Headache, pain around the jaw or behind the ear on the affected side

    • Decreased taste sensation

    • Changes in the amount of tears and saliva produced

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Levator anguli oris -muscle of upper lip innervated by upper buccal branch of facial nerve.

 

Option B. Buccinator -muscle of cheek innervated by lower buccal branch of facial nerve.

 

Option C. Mentalis-muscle of chin innervated by marginal mandibular branch of facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levator palpebrae superioris is innervated by upper division oculomotor nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 77

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of a sudden loss of taste on the front two-thirds of his tongue. He denies any facial weakness, ear pain, or changes in his ability to produce tears when he yawns or eats. He has no history of recent illness, trauma, or ear infections. Physical examination does not reveal any facial asymmetry or abnormality in lacrimation. Given these findings, you consider the anatomy of the facial nerve and its branches that convey taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Between Genu and Pyramidal Eminence

 

Option D:

 

 

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via its chorda tympani branch, which joins the lingual nerve (a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve) in the infratemporal fossa.

  • The chorda tympani originates from the facial nerve just before it exits the stylomastoid foramen.

  • A lesion at the geniculate ganglion or the internal auditory canal would likely present with additional symptoms such as facial weakness or hearing loss due to the involvement of other fibers of the facial nerve or adjacent structures.

  • The absence of decreased tear production (as indicated by a negative Schirmer test, which measures tear secretion) suggests that the lacrimal function, also mediated by the facial nerve but through its greater petrosal branch, is intact.

  • Therefore, the most probable site of lesion causing isolated loss of taste without affecting lacrimation or facial movement would be between the genu (where the nerve makes a sharp turn within the temporal bone) and the pyramidal eminence (before the exit at the stylomastoid foramen), where the chorda tympani branch separates from the main trunk of the facial nerve.

  • This specific location would affect taste fibers without impacting the stapedius muscle (innervated just after the pyramidal eminence) or the facial expression muscles (innervated after the nerve exits the stylomastoid foramen).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The facial nerve exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen, which is located between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone. This is where the facial nerve becomes vulnerable to compression or injury, leading to facial paralysis or other facial nerve-related symptoms. However, in this scenario, the patient does not present with facial weakness, so this option is less likely.

 

Option B: The geniculate ganglion is a swelling on the facial nerve located within the facial canal. It contains the cell bodies of the sensory fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Damage to this ganglion could result in loss of taste sensation on the affected side of the tongue. However, the patient's symptoms of sudden taste loss suggest a more distal lesion along the course of the nerve

 

Option C: The internal auditory canal is where the facial nerve enters the temporal bone alongside the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). Lesions at this site typically present with symptoms related to both the facial nerve (such as facial weakness) and the vestibulocochlear nerve (such as hearing loss or vertigo). Since the patient does not have any other symptoms suggestive of vestibulocochlear nerve involvement, this option is less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genu of the facial nerve is a sharp bend in its course as it passes around the medial side of the middle ear cavity. The pyramidal eminence is a bony prominence on the medial wall of the middle ear. Lesions between these two landmarks can affect the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve, which carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Damage to this branch could result in sudden loss of taste without affecting other functions of the facial nerve, such as facial movement or lacrimation. Therefore, lesion between genunand pyramidal eminence is the most likely explanation for the patient's symptoms.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 401

questions.text: All the following Muscles of Face are innervated by Facial Nerve except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Masseter
 

Option C:

 

  • All of the above muscles are facial muscle innervated by facial nerve except masseter which is a muscle of mastication and supplied by mandibular nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Levatorangulioris and other muscles of upper lip innervated by upper buccal branch of facial nerve.

 

 

Option B: Risorius is an upward continuation of platysma.

 

Option D: Buccinator is innervated by lower buccal branch of facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Masseter present over the outer surface of ramus of mandible innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

  • It covers the lateral aspect of the mandibular ramus and extends to the zygomatic arch of the cheekbone.

  • The primary function of the masseter muscle is to elevate the mandible, which closes the jaw during chewing.

  • It also plays a minor role in protruding the mandible.

  • The masseter is innervated by the masseteric nerve, a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is itself the third branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 77

questions.text: Structure passing through probed opening:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • The pointed structure is foramen rotundum.

  • The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (V2) passes through the foramen rotundum. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the mid-face, including the upper jaw and maxillary sinuses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3) passes through the foramen ovale. This nerve carries sensory and motor fibers to the face and jaw.

 

Option C: Several cranial nerves and blood vessels pass through the internal acoustic meatus:

 

  • Facial Nerve (VII): The facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus before exiting the skull.

  • Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): This nerve is responsible for hearing and balance. It also passes through the internal acoustic meatus.

  • Internal Auditory Artery and Vein: These blood vessels accompany the cranial nerves through the internal acoustic meatus.

 

Option D: Abducens nerve enters orbit through intermediate compartment of superior orbital fissure. The superior orbital fissure is a complex opening in the skull that allows various structures to pass through, including Oculomotor Nerve (III), Trochlear Nerve (IV), Ophthalmic Division of the Trigeminal Nerve (V1), Abducens Nerve (VI) Superior Ophthalmic Vein and Branches of the ophthalmic artery and sympathetic nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Foramen rotundum which connects the middle cranial fossa with pterygopalatine fossa and traversed by maxillary nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 41

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Remnant of Panniculus Carnosus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmaris Longus

 

Option B: Palmaris longus is not a remnant of panniculus carnosus. Palmaris longus muscle is present beneath deep fascia over the flexor surface of forearm and its tendon expands to form the palmar aponeurosis in hand. Palmaris brevis present subcutaneously over the hypothenar eminence is a remnant of panniculus carnosus.

 

Penniculus carnosus is a thin sheet of muscles present in subcutaneous fascias in lower animals.

 

Its remnants in humans include

  1. Muscles of facial expressions
  2. platysma 
  3. Subareolar muscle of breast
  4. Palmaris brevis
  5. Dartos in scrotum
  6. Corrugator cutis ani
  7. Auricularis anterior

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dartos is a subcutaneous smooth muscle present beneath the skin of scrotum, innervated by sympathetic fibres.

 

Option C: Occipitofrontalis subcutaneous muscle of the scalp innervated by facial nerve, its contraction moves the scalp forwards and backwards. The frontal belly of the occipitofrontalis is innervated by temporal branch of facial nerve. Occipital belly by posterior auricular branch of facial nerve

 

Option D: Auricularis anterior subcutaneous muscle of the auricle is innervated by temporal branch of facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palmaris longus muscle is present beneath deep fascia over the flexor surface of forearm and its tendon expands to form the palmar aponeurosis in hand. Palmaris brevis present subcutaneously over the hypothenar eminence is a remnant of panniculus carnosus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 77

questions.text: Muscle which divide Subclavian Artery into 3 parts:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scalenus Anterior

 

Option D:

 

 

The subclavian artery is anatomically divided into three parts by the Scalenus Anterior Muscle:

 

  1. First Part: Extends from the origin of the subclavian artery to the medial border of the scalenus anterior muscle. This segment typically gives rise to the vertebral artery, the internal thoracic artery, and the thyrocervical trunk.

  2. Second Part: Lies posterior to the scalenus anterior muscle. This segment usually gives rise to the costocervical trunk.

  3. Third Part: Extends from the lateral edge of the scalenus anterior muscle to the outer border of the first rib, where it continues as the axillary artery. The dorsal scapular artery can originate from this part if it does not arise from the thyrocervical trunk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Scalenus minimus contributes to the suprapleural membrane/Sibsonâ€™s fascia.

 

Option B: The trunks of brachial plexus lie between scalenus medius and scalenus anterior.

 

Option C: Scalenus posterior is inserted into outer surface of second rib.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subclavian artery is divided into 3 parts by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve seen on anterior surface of scalenus anterior.

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 332

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of an unusual problem. He notices that every time he eats or even thinks about sour foods, he experiences sweating and flushing on the right side of his face. He reports that this has been happening for the past six months. His medical history is significant for a right parotid gland tumor for which he underwent surgical resection one year ago. On physical examination, localized sweating and flushing are observed as shown in image on the cheek when he is given a lemon slice to smell. Which nerve is involved in the above clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Auricula Temporal Nerve

 

Option C: The regenerating secretomotor fibers of auriculotemporal nerve for the parotid gland gets misdirected into the sensory fibres of great auricular nerve that supplies the skin and sweat glands over the parotid gland resulting in gustatory sweating

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nerve of pterygoid canal carries preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres for lacrimal gland.

 

Option B: Chorda tympani carry preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres for submandibular and sublingual salivary gland.

 

Option D: Nerve to inferior oblique carries the preganglionic parasympathetic fibres for sphincter pupillae and ciliaris muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Freyâ€™s syndrome - The regenerating secretomotor fibers of auriculotemporal nerve for the parotid gland gets misdirected into the sensory fibres of great auricular nerve that supplies the skin and sweat glands over the parotid gland resulting in gustatory sweating.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 95,96

questions.text: Identify the nerve whose injury causes lateral gaze palsy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Option C:

 

  • Abducens nerve supplies lateral rectus muscle, injury to which cause lateral gaze palsy.

  • Abducens nerve lies in the floor of cavernous sinus lateral to internal carotid artery.

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

  1. Oculomotor Nerve

  2. Trochlear Nerve

  3. Abducens Nerve

  4. Ophthalmic division of Trigeminal Nerve

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It enters the orbit as upper and division through intermediate compartment of superior orbital fissure.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It enters the orbit through lateral compartment of superior orbital fissure.

 

Option D. Ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve lies in the lateral wall of cavernous sinus. It divides into lacrimal, frontal and nasociliary branches.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Abducens nerve supplies lateral rectus muscle, injury to which cause lateral gaze palsy.

  • Abducens nerve lies in the floor of cavernous sinus lateral to internal carotid artery.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg. 377

questions.text: An Incision to Remove Submandibular Salivary Gland can damage all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Buccal Nerve

 

Option D: Buccal nerve is less likely to be damaged during an incision to remove the submandibular salivary gland due to its location and the typical surgical approach to gland removal.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypoglossal nerve rests over hyoglossus and is related to the medial surface and cervical branch of facial nerve to the inferior surface of the gland. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) runs close to the submandibular gland, especially as it travels in the submandibular region towards the tongue. It is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue. Damage to this nerve during surgery can lead to tongue weakness or paralysis on the affected side.

 

Option B: The lingual presents a triple relation to the duct of the submandibular gland. Initially lies above and lateral, then winds around its lower border, then ascends medial to it. The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), provides sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and the floor of the mouth. It runs close to the submandibular gland and duct, making it susceptible to injury during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Option C: An incision to remove submandibular gland is placed 2 to 4 cm below lower border of mandible to avoid injury to marginal mandibular nerve. The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve (CN VII) provides motor innervation to the muscles of the lower lip and chin. It runs just below the mandible and may be at risk during an incision for submandibular gland removal, especially if the incision is extended or dissection is carried too far anteriorly or superiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Buccal Nerve, another branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), provides sensory innervation to the skin over the buccal (cheek) region and the mucous membrane of the cheek.

 

 

  • Given its location, it is less likely to be in the field of surgical dissection for submandibular gland removal, which is more inferior and medial compared to the usual course of the buccal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 121

questions.text: Lateral Atlanto Axial Joint is an example of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plane Joint

 

Option C:

 

 

  • It is an example of a plane type of synovial joint. The lateral atlantoaxial joint between the inferior articular facet on the lateral mass of atlas with the superior articular facet of axis is a plane synovial joint.

  • The median atlantoaxial joint is formed between the dens of axis and an osteoligamentous ring of the atlas anteriorly and transverse ligament posteriorly.

  • It is classified as a pivot joint. The lateral atlantoaxial joints are bilateral joints formed between the lateral masses of the atlas and axis. These joints are classified as gliding, or plane joints.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Median atlantoaxial joints are pivot synovial joints which permit rotational movements and are also called as joints of No

 

Option B: The Atlanto Occipital Joints are ellipsoidal synovial joints and permit flexion, extension, lateral flexion and are called joints of yes.

 

Option D: Saddle synovial joint in head and neck region includes the incudomalleal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral atlanto-axial joint is an example of a plane joint. This type of synovial joint allows for rotation around a single axis. In the case of the lateral atlanto-axial joint, it permits the rotation of the head, as seen when shaking the head "no."

  • The joint is formed between the C1 vertebra (also known as the atlas) and the C2 vertebra (also known as the axis). The defining feature of this pivot joint is the odontoid process (or dens) of the axis, around which the atlas rotates.

  • This specific structure and function allow for a significant range of rotational movement, which is crucial for head and neck mobility.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 59

choices.text: Posterior to Superior Turbinate
Posterior to Middle Turbinate
Posterior to Inferior Turbinate
Inferior to Superior Turbinate

questions.text: Woodruff’s Plexus is located over:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior to Inferior Turbinate

 

Option C:

 

  • Woodruff's plexus is a vascular network located on the posterior lateral wall of the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity and it is generally considered to be responsible for posterior epistaxis.
  • Sphenopalatine artery is called the artery of epistaxis

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior and middle turbinate are parts of labyrinth of ethmoid bone.

 

Option B: Anterior epistaxis results from injury to kissel bach’s plexus located over anteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option D: Inferior turbinate is the largest and is an independent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Woodruff's plexus, also known as Woodruff's area, is a venous plexus located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, near the posterior end of the inferior nasal concha or turbinate.
  • It is situated over the posterior nasal septum and the lateral nasal wall, particularly in the region of the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • This plexus is known for being a potential source of posterior epistaxis due to its rich vascularization and location.
  • The veins of Woodruff's plexus are connected to the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 219

questions.text: Nasal Septum is formed by ALL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perpendicular Plate of Palatine Bone

 

Option A: The nasal septum receives minor contribution from palatine crest whereas the perpendicular plate of palatine bone contributes to lateral wall of nose.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the anterosuperior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option C: Vomer, the unpaired bone contributes to the posteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option D: Minor contribution to the septum in its posterosuperior portion comes from the sphenoidal crest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasal septum is the structure that divides the nasal cavity into two nostrils (or nasal passages). It is composed of both bone and cartilage. The nasal septum is formed by:

 

  1. Perpendicular Plate of the Ethmoid Bone: This is a thin, vertical bone that forms the superior part of the nasal septum. The ethmoid bone is one of the cranial bones and contributes significantly to the structure of the nasal cavity.

  2. Vomer Bone: The vomer is a thin, plow-shaped bone that forms the inferior and posterior parts of the nasal septum. It articulates above with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone and below with the maxillary and palatine bones.

  3. Septal Cartilage (Quadrangular Cartilage): This is a flexible cartilage that fills in the anterior part of the nasal septum. It extends from the nasal bones in the roof of the nose down to the maxillary bones in the floor.

 

Note: Do not confuse between perpendicular plate of ethmoid and palatine. The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to nasal septum whereas the perpendicular plate of palatine does not

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 20

questions.text: Skin over Angle of Mandible innervated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Great Auricular Nerve

 

Option C: The sensory innervation to the face is from the tree divisions of trigeminal nerve except the skin over the angle of the mandible which is innervated by the great auricular nerve from cervical plexus C2, C3.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve supplies the skin over lower lip, chin, over mandible excluding its Angle, part of Pinna, External Acoustic Meatus and most of the temple.

 

Option B: Maxillary division of trigeminal nerve supplies the skin over upper lip, part of the side of nose, lower eyelid, lower eyelid, malar prominence and small portion of temple.

 

Option D: Infratrochlear nerve, branch of ophthalmic nerve which supplies skin over tip and side of nose, upper eyelid and forehead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The skin over the angle of mandible is primarily innervated by the great auricular nerve.

  • The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus, arising from the ventral rami of C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends along the sternocleidomastoid muscle, then curves around its posterior border to reach the skin over the parotid gland, the angle of the mandible, and the area around the ear.

 

 

  • This nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin in these areas, making it responsible for the sensation over the angle of the mandible.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 85

choices.text: Contains Third Part of Maxillary Artery
Medially communicates with Infratemporal Fossa
Communicates with Middle through Foramen Rotundum
Vidian Nerve Canal opens into it

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Pterygopalatine Fossa:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medially communicates with Infratemporal Fossa.

 

Option B:

 

  • The pterygopalatine fossa is a deep, cone-shaped space located between the maxilla, the sphenoid bone, and the palatine bone.

 

Location: The pterygopalatine fossa is situated posterior to the maxilla, anterior to the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone, and superior to the palatine bone.

 

Boundaries:

 

  • Anterior: The posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior: The root of the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone.
  • Medial: The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.
  • Lateral: The pterygomaxillary fissure, which connects the fossa to the infratemporal fossa.
  • Superior: The body of the sphenoid bone.
  • Inferior: The palatine bone, specifically the horizontal plate, leading into the oral cavity.

 

Contents:

 

The pterygopalatine fossa contains several important structures:

 

  • The maxillary nerve (V2), the second branch of the trigeminal nerve, which enters the fossa through the foramen rotundum.
  • The pterygopalatine ganglion, which hangs from the maxillary nerve and is associated with the facial nerve (CN VII) for parasympathetic innervation.
  • Branches of the maxillary artery, which is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Veins that correspond to the branches of the maxillary artery, forming the pterygoid plexus.

 

Connections: The pterygopalatine fossa connects to other regions through several openings, allowing the passage of nerves and vessels:

 

  • Inferiorly: To the oral cavity via the greater and lesser palatine canals.
  • Laterally: To the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure.
  • Medially: To the nasal cavity via the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • Superiorly: To the orbit via the inferior orbital fissure.
  • Posteriorly: To the middle cranial fossa via the foramen rotundum and to the pterygoid canal.

 

These connections make the pterygopalatine fossa a crucial crossroads for the distribution of nerves and vessels to the face, orbit, nasal cavity, and palate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maxillary artery divided by lateral pterygoid muscle into 3 parts. The first and second part lie in infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Maxillary division of trigeminal nerve reaches pterygopalatine fossa via foramen rotundum.

 

Option D: Nerve of pterygoid canal reaches pterygopalatine fossa from middle cranial fossa via vidain nerve canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygopalatine fossa medially related to perpendicular plate of palatine bone and laterally communicates with infratemporal fossa.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 110

choices.text: Anterior Superior Alveolar Nerve
Middle Superior Alveolar Nerve
Posterior Superior Alveolar Nerve
Inferior Alveolar Nerve

questions.text: Upper Premolars are supplied by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle superior alveolar nerve

 

Option B: The middle superior alveolar nerve arises from infraorbital nerve, branch from maxillary division of trigeminal nerve and supplies upper premolars.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Canine and incisors of upper jaw-anterior superior alveolar nerve from infraorbital nerve, branch from maxillary division of trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C: Molars of upper jaw -posterior superior alveolar nerve from maxillary division of trigeminal nerve

 

 

Option D: Lower jaw dentition -inferior alveolar nerve from mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Upper premolars are supplied by branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2). Specifically, the innervation to the upper premolars comes from the middle superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the infraorbital nerve, which itself is a branch of the maxillary nerve.
  • The first upper premolar may also receive some innervation from the anterior superior alveolar nerve, another branch of the infraorbital nerve.
  • Additionally, the blood supply to the upper premolars is primarily from the posterior superior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The maxillary artery is one of the two terminal branches of the external carotid artery.


Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 364

questions.text: In the given image the nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left Hypoglossal Nerve

 

Option D:

 

The given image shows deviation of tip of tongue to left side on protrusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Lingual nerve is purely sensory to the tongue and arises from posterior division of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

 

Option B. Left Lingual nerve carries general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

 

Option C. Hypoglossal nerve innervates all muscles of tongue except palatoglossus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypoglossal nerve injury the tip of the protruded tongue deviates to the paralysed side.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 148

choices.text: Deviation of Tongue to Same Side
Loss of Taste Sensation in Same Side of Tongue

questions.text: Unilateral Injury to Hypoglossal Nerve leads to all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of Taste Sensation in Same Side of Tongue

 

Option C:

 

  • Unilateral Injury to the Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) can lead to a variety of symptoms related to its primary function, which is the motor innervation of the muscles of the tongue.

  • Taste sensation from tongue: Anterior 2/3 -chorda tympani branch of facial nerve, Posterior 1/3 + circumvallate papillae â€“ IX nerve and Posterior most â€“ X nerve.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True. The hypoglossal nerve innervates the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve). Injury to the hypoglossal nerve can lead to weakness and atrophy of the tongue muscles on the affected side due to denervation. Over time, this can result in noticeable hemiatrophy of the tongue on the side of the injury.

 

 

Option B: True. When the hypoglossal nerve is injured on one side, the tongue muscles on that side become weaker. When the patient attempts to protrude the tongue, it will deviate towards the weakened (affected) side. This is because the normal or unaffected side pushes the tongue towards the weakened side.

 

Option D: True. Fasciculations are involuntary, spontaneous muscle twitches that can occur as a result of nerve damage. When the hypoglossal nerve is injured, it can lead to fasciculations in the muscles of the tongue on the affected side. These fasciculations are often visible on the surface of the tongue and are a sign of lower motor neuron damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of Taste Sensation in Same Side of Tongue: False.

 

  • The hypoglossal nerve is primarily a motor nerve and does not carry taste sensations.

  • Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani (a branch of the facial nerve, CN VII), while the posterior one-third's taste sensation is carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

  • Therefore, a unilateral injury to the hypoglossal nerve would not affect taste sensation.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 138

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gasserian Ganglion

 

Option D: The pointed structure is the trigeminal ganglion in fossa of dura mater called Gasserian ganglion.

 

Gasserian ganglion: It contains pseudounipolar neurons.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Langley’s ganglia is the other name for submandibular ganglia. Langley's ganglion isn't a widely recognized term in standard anatomical nomenclature. It could potentially be a less common name for a specific ganglion, possibly related to the work of John Newport Langley, an English physiologist who made significant contributions to the understanding of the autonomic nervous system.

 

Option B: Meckel’s ganglia is the other name for pterygopalatine ganglion, is located in the pterygopalatine fossa, near the maxillary nerve. It is a parasympathetic ganglion that plays a crucial role in innervating the lacrimal glands (contributing to tear production) and various glands in the nasal cavity and palate. It involves functions such as nasal secretion and dilation of blood vessels in the nasal cavity.

 

Option C: Geniculate ganglion is located at the external genu of facial nerve. The geniculate ganglion is a sensory ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) located in the facial canal. It contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons that bring taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and cutaneous sensations from the external ear. It is also involved in the sensory pathway for the facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gasserian ganglion, more commonly known as the trigeminal ganglion, is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), the largest of the cranial nerves. It is located in a cavity called Meckel's cave, part of the temporal bone. This ganglion contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons that carry information from the face, including touch, pain, and temperature sensations. The trigeminal nerve has three major branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves, which innervate different regions of the face.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg380

choices.text: Loss of Transverse wrinkles of Forehead

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Facial Nerve Injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inability to Open the Eyes

 

Option C: Orbicularis oculi innervated by facial nerves helps in the closure of eyes. In facial nerve palsy patient will present with inability to close the eyes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Loss of transverse wrinkles of the forehead is a feature of facial nerve injury. The facial nerve controls the frontalis muscle, which is responsible for raising the eyebrows and creating transverse wrinkles on the forehead. In facial nerve injury, the ability to raise the eyebrows on the affected side is lost.

 

Option B: Corneal reflex disturbed is a feature of facial nerve injury. The facial nerve plays a role in the corneal reflex, which involves the blink reflex in response to corneal stimulation. Damage to the facial nerve can lead to a disturbed or absent corneal reflex on the affected side. The afferent limb of corneal reflex is via ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve and efferent limb is via facial nerve.

 

Option D: Decreased lacrimation is a feature of facial nerve injury. The facial nerve also controls the lacrimal glands responsible for tear production. Facial nerve injury can lead to decreased or absent tear production on the affected side, resulting in dryness of the eye. The preganglionic parasympathetic fibre for lacrimal gland passes via nervus intermedius component of facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inability to open eyes is not typically associated with facial nerve injury. Facial nerve injury primarily affects the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for closing the eyes. While facial nerve injury can lead to difficulty in closing the eye (lagophthalmos), it does not usually result in an inability to open the eyes. Levator palpebrae superioris elevates the upper eyelid to open the palpebral fissure and is innervated by upper division of oculomotor nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 393

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower division of III Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • Pointed structure is medial rectus muscle.

  • The medial rectus muscle, which is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for eye movement, is indeed supplied by the lower division of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, not the medial rectus. The superior oblique muscle turns the eye downward and laterally.

 

Option B. The upper division of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) innervates the superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris muscles. The superior rectus muscle elevates the eye, while the levator palpebrae superioris raises the upper eyelid.

 

Option D. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally, away from the nose).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medial rectus muscle lies in the medial wall of orbit below the superior oblique muscle.  It is innervated by Lower division of III nerve.

  • Lower Division of III Nerve: The lower division of the oculomotor nerve innervates the medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. The medial rectus muscle moves the eye medially (towards the nose).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 256

choices.text: Angle of Mandible
Transverse Process of C7
Great Cornu of Hyoid

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of blocking of Superior Laryngeal Nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Great Cornu of Hyoid

 

Option D:

 

  • Superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus.
  • Needle is inserted from lateral side of neck aiming at greater cornu of hyoid to block the nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior laryngeal divides into external and internal laryngeal nerves. ELN is entirely motor and supplies cricothyroid muscle. The angle of the mandible is too far anterior and superior to the course of the superior laryngeal nerve and is not an appropriate site for blocking this nerve.

 

Option B: Cricoid cartilage lies opposite C6 vertebral level. The cricoid cartilage is located inferior to the area where the superior laryngeal nerve branches off the vagus nerve, making it a less suitable location for blocking this specific nerve.

 

Option C: Inferior cervical ganglion is located at C7 level. The transverse process of the C7 vertebra is too inferior and is not related to the course of the superior laryngeal nerve. This site is not used for blocking the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), can be blocked to provide anesthesia to the upper part of the larynx. The most suitable site for blocking the superior laryngeal nerve is near the great cornu of the hyoid bone.

 

The superior laryngeal nerve divides into two branches: the internal and external laryngeal nerves. The internal laryngeal nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords, passes medially to the thyrohyoid membrane, which is closely related to the greater horn (cornu) of the hyoid bone. Anesthetizing the superior laryngeal nerve at this point effectively blocks sensation to the upper larynx.

choices.text: Upper Deep Cervical Nodes
Lymphatic Tissue over Posterior 1/3 Tongue

questions.text: Component of Inner Waldeyer Ring are ALL Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper Deep Cervical Nodes 

 

Option A: Upper deep cervical nodes include the jugulodigastric nodes which are the principal lymph nodes of the palatine tonsil.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Tubal tonsil -part of waldeyer ring found in lateral wall of nasopharynx overlying tubal elevation.

 

Option C: Palatine tonsil part of waldeyer ring found in lateral wall of oropharynx.

 

Option D: Lymphatic tissue over posterior 1/3 tongue contribute to Lingual tonsil and part of waldeyer ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Waldeyer's ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue located in the throat and nasopharynx.
  • It forms part of the body's immune system by encircling the entrance to the pharynx and providing a defense against inhaled and ingested pathogens.
  • The Waldeyer's ring includes both outer and inner components.

 

The inner components of the Waldeyer's ring typically refer to the lymphoid tissues that are situated more deeply or posteriorly in the nasopharynx and oropharynx. These include:

 

  1. Pharyngeal Tonsil (Adenoids): Located in the roof of the nasopharynx, the pharyngeal tonsil enlarges during childhood and tends to atrophy with age. It is a significant part of the body's immune defense, especially in children.
  2. Tubal Tonsils: These are located near the openings of the Eustachian tubes in the nasopharynx. The tubal tonsils are smaller lymphoid tissues that, along with the adenoids and other components, form the ring of lymphoid tissue.
  3. Lingual Tonsil: Situated at the base of the tongue, the lingual tonsil is part of the Waldeyer's ring, contributing to the immune defense at the entrance of the oropharynx and laryngopharynx.

 

The outer components typically refer to the more anteriorly placed palatine tonsils, which are located at the sides of the throat, and sometimes the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches, which are muscular folds adjacent to the palatine tonsils.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

choices.text: Occipital Lymph Node
Submental Lymph Node
Deep Cervical Nodes

questions.text: Tip of Tongue drains into:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Submental Lymph Node

 

Option B:

 

Lymphatics from tip of tongue pierce mylohyoid and drain into submental lymph nodes

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Occipital nodes receive lymph from posterior part of scalp.

 

Option C: The lower deep cervical lymph nodes, especially jugulo omohyoid nodes are the principal lymph nodes of tongue.

 

Option D: Jugulodigastric nodes are the principal lymph nodes of palatine tonsil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lymphatic drainage of the tongue is complex and involves several groups of lymph nodes, primarily due to the tongue's role in oral functions and its exposure to various pathogens. The drainage patterns vary between the anterior and posterior parts of the tongue:
 

 

Anterior Two-Thirds of the Tongue

 

  • The lymph from the tip and the lateral margins of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue generally drains to the submental lymph nodes.
  • The central part of the anterior two-thirds drains to the submandibular lymph nodes.
  • Some lymph from the lateral parts of the anterior two-thirds may also drain directly to the deep cervical lymph nodes, bypassing the submandibular nodes.

 

Posterior One-Third of the Tongue

 

  • The lymph from the posterior one-third of the tongue, which includes the area around the lingual tonsils, drains primarily to the deep cervical lymph nodes, especially the upper deep cervical nodes. This drainage can occur directly or via the jugulodigastric nodes (a subset of the deep cervical lymph nodes located around the junction of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the internal jugular vein).
  • There is also a potential for cross-drainage between the two sides of the tongue, meaning that lymph from one side of the tongue can drain to lymph nodes on the opposite side.
  • Floor of the Mouth
  • The lymphatics from the floor of the mouth, closely associated with the ventral surface of the tongue, primarily drain to the submandibular lymph nodes, with some drainage to the submental lymph nodes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 150

questions.text: A 50-year-old female went to her family physician with complaints of pain over her lower neck for the past 2 months. The pain had increased over the past three days. She insisted that an x-ray should be taken. The given image is the x-ray of the patient. Which of the following is not a feature of cervical vertebra?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral Foramen is Small & Circular

 

Option B:

 

  • Vertebral foramen is large & triangular for accomodation of cervical enlargement of spinal cord.
     

   

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is true. The uncinate processes, also known as the uncus or uncal process, are hook-shaped processes on the lateral edges of the top surface of the bodies of the third to the seventh cervical vertebrae. They are involved in the formation of the uncovertebral joints (joints of Luschka), which are unique to the cervical spine, the upper surface of which presents with raised lips called uncal process.

 

Option C: This is true for most cervical vertebrae (C2-C6). The spinous processes of these vertebrae are typically short and bifid (split at the end), which is a distinctive feature of cervical vertebrae, allowing for greater movement and muscle attachment.

 

Option D: This is true. The cervical vertebrae are unique in having the foramen transversarium within each transverse process. These foramina serve as passages for the vertebral arteries (except for the seventh cervical vertebra, where the foramen transversarium may transmit only accessory veins rather than the artery).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vertebral foramen in cervical vertebrae is actually relatively large and triangular (or heart-shaped) to accommodate the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord.

  • This feature is more characteristic of thoracic vertebrae, where the vertebral foramen tends to be smaller and more circular. Therefore, option B is not a feature of cervical vertebrae.

 

Ref: Grayâ€™s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 720

choices.text: Superior Oblique and Superior Rectus
Medial and Lateral Rectus
Inferior Rectus and Inferior Oblique
LPS and Superior Rectus

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of double vision and difficulty looking downward, especially when navigating stairs. She reports a sensation of heaviness in her right eye and occasional pain behind the eye when attempting to read. On examination, there is a noticeable limitation in the downward movement of the right eye. The rest of the cranial nerve examination is within normal limits. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely involved in the pathophysiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Rectus and Inferior Oblique

 

Option C:

 

  • The suspensory ligament of Lockwood, also known as Lockwood's ligament, is an important structure in the orbit that helps support the eyeball and maintains its position within the orbital cavity.
  • It is particularly involved with the lower eyelid and the structures of the inferior aspect of the eye.
  • It acts as a hammock-like support for the eyeball, particularly encircling and supporting the inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.
  • The inferior rectus muscle is primarily responsible for downward gaze, while the inferior oblique assists in eye movements, particularly in extorsion and elevation of the eye.
  • The patient's symptoms of double vision (diplopia) and difficulty in looking downward suggest an issue with the muscles responsible for these movements, pointing towards a problem associated with the suspensory ligament of Lockwood, which supports these muscles.
  • The limitation in downward movement of the eye, in particular, implicates the inferior rectus muscle, which is supported by this ligament.
  • Tenon’s capsule or fascia bulbi forms a membranous envelope for the eyeball. Its lower part is thickened to form suspensory ligament of lockwood that encloses Inferior rectus and inferior oblique.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This option is incorrect. The superior oblique and superior rectus muscles are located in the upper part of the orbital cavity and are not primarily supported by Lockwood's ligament. The superior oblique muscle is involved in downward and outward eye movements, while the superior rectus elevates the eye. Lockwood's ligament is more associated with the structures of the inferior orbit. Suspensory ligament suspends the eyeball from below.

 

Option B: This option is also incorrect. The medial and lateral rectus muscles are responsible for moving the eye medially and laterally, respectively. While these muscles are important for horizontal eye movements, they are not the primary structures supported by Lockwood's ligament. Suspensory ligament connects the medial check ligament of medial rectus with the lateral check ligament of lateral rectus.

 

Option D: This option is incorrect. The Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid, and the superior rectus, as mentioned, elevates the eye. Both these structures are located superiorly in the orbit and are not primarily supported by the suspensory ligament of Lockwood, which is more concerned with the inferior orbital structures. Whitnall's tubercle on the lateral wall of the orbit receives the attachment of suspensory ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The suspensory ligament of Lockwood forms a hammock-like support that helps to cradle the eyeball, particularly influencing the position and function of the inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.
  • The inferior rectus muscle depresses the eye, while the inferior oblique muscle is involved in elevating the eye and rotating it outward.
  • Lockwood's ligament provides support to these muscles and the lower part of the eyeball, contributing to the stability of the eye within the orbit and ensuring proper functioning of these muscles.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 263

questions.text: Maxillary Bone does not articulate with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sphenoid

 

Option B:

 

  • Maxilla articulates with the following bones- Frontal, Ethmoidal, Lacrimal, Nasal, Inferior Concha, Zygomatic, Palatine, Vomer.

  • It doesnâ€™t articulate with sphenoid bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Medially, the maxilla articulates with the ethmoid bone, specifically at the ethmoidal sinuses and the middle nasal concha.

 

Option C: The maxilla articulates anteriorly with the lacrimal bone, contributing to the medial wall of the orbit.

 

Option D: Frontal Bone articulates superiorly with the frontal bone, contributing to the formation of the floor of the orbit and the lateral walls and floor of the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary bone, also known as the maxilla, articulates with several bones in the skull, including frontal, lacrimal, ethmoid and

 

  • Inferior Nasal Concha: The maxilla articulates with the inferior nasal concha, which is part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

  • Palatine Bone: Posteriorly, the maxilla articulates with the horizontal plate of the palatine bone, helping to form the hard palate.

  • Zygomatic Bone: Laterally, the maxilla articulates with the zygomatic bone, contributing to the prominence of the cheek and the lateral wall and floor of the orbit.

  • Vomer: The maxilla also articulates with the vomer bone along its posterior aspect, particularly at the nasal septum.

  • Nasal Bones: The maxilla articulates with the two nasal bones at the bridge of the nose, contributing to the upper part of the nasal septum and the lateral walls of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the clinic with numbness and tingling on the upper part of her right ear. She denies any trauma or injury to the ear but mentions recent episodes of severe headaches. On physical examination, the sensation is diminished on the anterior surface of the pinna and around the tragus. The rest of the cranial nerve examination is within normal limits. Given the distribution of her sensory loss, which of the following nerves is least likely to be involved in the innervation of the affected area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tympanic Branch of Glossopharyngeal Nerve

 

Option D:

 

 

  • The pinna (external ear) receives its sensory innervation from several cranial and cervical nerves.

  • The auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, CN V3) supplies the anterior aspect of the ear and the area around the tragus, where the patient reports numbness and tingling.

  • The great auricular nerve (a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves) innervates the lower part of the pinna and the area behind the ear.

  • The lesser occipital nerve (also originating from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves) supplies the upper part of the pinna and the scalp behind the ear.

  • The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as Jacobson's nerve, is primarily involved in the innervation of the middle ear cavity, not the external ear. Hence it is the branch which is least likely to be injured because as per the clinical symptoms mentioned in the question, it is evident that the area of the external ear near the tragus is involved.

  • It contributes to the tympanic plexus on the promontory of the middle ear and is involved in the sensation of the middle ear mucosa and the auditory tube.

  • Therefore, it is not involved in the sensory innervation of the pinna and is the correct answer to the question, as it does not contribute to the nerve supply of the pinna, where the patient's symptoms are localized.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3, which is the third branch of the trigeminal nerve), does supply the pinna. It innervates the anterior and inferior portions of the external ear, as well as the external auditory meatus and the outer surface of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option B: The great auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus (arising from C2 and C3 spinal nerves), also supplies the pinna. It innervates the skin over the lower part of the pinna and the area behind the ear.

 

Option C: The lesser occipital nerve, another branch of the cervical plexus, innervates the skin of the neck and scalp posterior to the ear. While it is in close proximity to the pinna, its primary innervation is not the pinna itself but the area around it. However, there might be some overlapping sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nerves supplying pinna-Auriculotemporal nerve, Great auricular nerve, Lesser occipital nerve and Auricular branch of vagus.

  • Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve forms tympanic plexus in middle ear cavity and doesnâ€™t innervate pinna.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 275

choices.text: Superior Petrosal Sinus
Inferior Petrosal Sinus
Deep Middle Cerebral Vein
Superficial Middle Cerebral Vein

questions.text: Cavernous sinus receives input from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superficial Middle Cerebral Vein

 

Option D:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A & B: Superior and inferior petrosal sinus are the outgoing channels of cavernous sinus. Cavernous sinus communicates with transverse sinus via superior petrosal sinus and with internal jugular vein via inferior petrosal sinus.

 

Option C: Deep middle cerebral vein unites with anterior cerebral vein and striate veins to form the basal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superficial middle cerebral vein lies over the posterior ramus of the lateral sulcus and drains the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere into cavernous sinus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 351

questions.text: Extrinsic Membranes of Larynx are ALL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quadrate Membrane

 

Option A: Quadrate membrane is an intrinsic membrane, its upper margin lies in the aryepiglottic fold and lower border thickened to form vestibular membrane
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and internal laryngeal nerve

 

 

Option C: Hyoepiglottic ligament connects lower part of anterior surface of epiglottis to hyoid bone.

 

Option D: Cricotracheal membrane extends from the lower border of anterior arch to first tracheal ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The extrinsic membranes of the larynx are connective tissue structures that connect the larynx to adjacent parts of the throat and help to support and stabilize it. There are two main extrinsic membranes of the larynx:
  1. Thyrohyoid Membrane stretches between the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage. It is a broad, fibroelastic sheet that connects the upper border of the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone. The thyrohyoid membrane is important for suspending the larynx from the hyoid bone and for facilitating the movement and function of the larynx during speech and swallowing. The membrane has a central and lateral part, where the lateral part is thickened to form the thyrohyoid ligament.
  2. Cricotracheal Ligament (or Membrane) connects the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, which is the base of the larynx, to the first tracheal ring, effectively joining the larynx to the trachea. It provides continuity between the larynx above and the trachea below, ensuring a stable yet flexible airway that can accommodate movements such as swallowing, neck flexion, and extension.
  • The intrinsic membranes of the larynx, often referred to as intrinsic ligaments, are a series of connective tissue structures that connect the various cartilages of the larynx to each other. Unlike the extrinsic membranes that connect the larynx to other structures in the neck, the intrinsic membranes are entirely contained within the larynx and play a crucial role in its function, including voice production and the opening and closing of the glottis. The main intrinsic membranes and ligaments include:
  1. Conus Elasticus (Cricovocal Membrane) extends from the cricoid cartilage up to the vocal ligaments. It is comprised of two parts:
      • The medial cricothyroid ligament, which is a thickened band in the midline, stretching between the cricoid and thyroid cartilages.
      • The lateral cricothyroid membranes, which extend from the cricoid cartilage to the vocal ligaments and arytenoid cartilages.
  2. Quadrangular Membranes are paired membranes that stretch between the epiglottis, the arytenoid cartilages, and the thyroid cartilage. The free lower edges of the quadrangular membranes form the vestibular ligaments (or false vocal cords), which run parallel to the true vocal cords but are located just above them.
  3. Vocal Ligaments are not membranes per se but are often included in discussions of the intrinsic structures of the larynx due to their importance in voice production. The vocal ligaments are bands of elastic tissue that stretch from the thyroid cartilage in front to the arytenoid cartilage at the back. They are covered by a layer of mucous membrane and form the core of the true vocal cords (or vocal folds).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 236

questions.text: Torticollis is due to Spasm of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sternocleidomastoid

 

Option C:

 

Spasm of sternocleidomastoid produces wry neck/torticollis where chin is turned to opposite side and head to the same side as of the shoulder.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Platysma reduces the concavity of neck and relieves pressure over the veins.

 

Option B: Trapezius innervated by spinal accessory nerve, injury to which patient unable to shrug his shoulders.

 

Option D: Serratus anterior innervated by long thoracic nerve, injury to which produces winging of scapula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Torticollis, also known as "wry neck," is characterized by an abnormal, asymmetrical head or neck position, which can be due to a variety of causes. When it occurs as a result of muscular spasm, it is most commonly associated with the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

  • This muscle runs along each side of the neck, from the sternum and clavicle up to the mastoid process of the skull.

  • In cases of torticollis involving the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the muscle on one side may contract involuntarily, tilting the head towards the affected side and rotating the chin upwards and towards the opposite side.

  • This can be due to congenital factors, acquired muscle injury, inflammation, or other underlying conditions affecting the neuromuscular system.
     

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 185

choices.text: Tonsillar Branch of Facial Artery
Ascending Palatine Artery
Descending Palatine Artery
Ascending Pharyngeal Artery

questions.text: Which of the following does not Supply Palate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tonsillar Branch of Facial Artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery primarily supplies the palatine tonsil and surrounding tissues, not the palate itself.
  • While it is in close proximity to the palate, its main function is to provide blood to the tonsillar area. Therefore, this artery does not directly supply the palate.

 

 

Explanation:
