Option B: The ascending palatine artery, a branch of the facial artery, indeed supplies the palate. It ascends between the styloglossus and stylopharyngeus muscles and contributes to the blood supply of the soft palate and tonsils.

 

Option C: Descending palatine artery, which arises from the maxillary artery, is a major supplier of blood to the hard and soft palate. It typically divides into the greater and lesser palatine arteries, which supply the hard and soft palate, respectively.

 

Option D: The ascending pharyngeal artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, primarily supplies the pharynx. While it has branches that contribute to the blood supply of the pharynx and adjacent structures, it is not a primary supplier of the palate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blood supply of the palate is derived from several branches of the maxillary artery, which is one of the two terminal branches of the external carotid artery. The main arteries supplying the palate include:

 

  1. Greater Palatine Artery is the primary artery supplying the hard palate. It descends through the greater palatine canal, emerges from the greater palatine foramen, and supplies the mucosa and glands of the hard palate, except for a small area near the alveolar margin which is supplied by the nasopalatine artery.
  2. Lesser Palatine Arteries supply the soft palate. They descend through the lesser palatine canals and emerge through the lesser palatine foramina to supply the soft palate, uvula, and tonsils.
  3. A branch of the facial artery, the ascending palatine artery, contributes to the supply of the soft palate by ascending along the pharynx.
  4. Pharyngeal Branches of the Maxillary Artery branches may also contribute to the blood supply of the soft palate.
  5. Nasopalatine Artery runs forward on the nasal septum and supplies a small part of the anterior hard palate through the incisive canal.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 131

questions.text: Chief Source of Blood Supply to Parathyroid Glands is from:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Thyroid Artery

 

Option C:

 

 

  • The chief source of blood supply to the parathyroid glands is typically from the inferior thyroid arteries.

  • These arteries branch from the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery.

  • The inferior thyroid arteries give off small branches that supply the parathyroid glands, which are located on the posterior aspect of the thyroid gland.

  • While the superior thyroid artery (a branch of the external carotid artery) can also supply the parathyroid glands, especially the superior parathyroid glands, the inferior thyroid artery is generally considered the main source of vascular supply to both the superior and inferior parathyroid glands due to its proximity and the presence of multiple small branches that directly supply the glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior thyroid artery gives rise to infrahyoid, cricothyroid, sternomastoid, superior laryngeal and glandular branches.

 

Option B: Superior laryngeal artery pierces thyrohyoid membrane along with internal laryngeal nerve.

 

Option D: Cricothyroid artery arises from superior thyroid artery and passes across cricothyroid ligament to anastomose with artery of opposite side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior thyroid artery that arises from thyrocervical trunk of first part of subclavian artery provides chief source of blood supply to parathyroid glands and also provides branches to supply trachea, oesophagus and pharynx.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 308

choices.text: Greater Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a chronic headache localized to the forehead and behind the eyes. He also reports a decreased sense of smell and episodes of nasal congestion not relieved by over-the-counter medications. Imaging studies, including a CT scan of the sinuses, show opacification of the sphenoidal sinuses with bone remodeling. Given the location of his sinus disease, which of the following structures is most at risk of being affected by the pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vidian Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • The canal for vidian nerve/ pterygoid canal lies in the floor of the sphenoidal sinus.
  • Vidian nerve, also known as the nerve of the pterygoid canal, runs in the pterygoid canal and carries fibers from the greater petrosal nerve (parasympathetic) and the deep petrosal nerve (sympathetic).
  • It is located near the floor of the sphenoidal sinus. Pathology in the sphenoidal sinus, such as chronic inflammation, infection, or tumor, can potentially impact the Vidian nerve due to its anatomical proximity.
  • This could result in symptoms related to its autonomic functions, including altered lacrimation or salivation, though these are more subtle and less commonly reported by patients compared to the more prominent symptoms of sphenoid sinus disease like headache and nasal congestion.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mandibular nerve passes through foramen ovale in middle cranial fossa to enter infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Greater petrosal nerve arises from geniculate ganglion pierces roof of middle ear lies over the groove on it.

 

Option D: Maxillary nerve passes through foramen rotundum of middle cranial fossa to reach pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Vidian nerve, also known as the nerve of the pterygoid canal, does not lie directly over the floor of the sphenoidal sinus.
  • The structure that lies directly over the floor of the sphenoidal sinus is typically the sphenoid bone itself, which forms the roof of the nasopharynx.
  • The Vidian nerve runs in the pterygoid canal, which is situated more laterally, in the base of the skull, connecting the foramen lacerum to the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The Vidian nerve is formed by the union of the greater petrosal nerve, carrying parasympathetic fibers, and the deep petrosal nerve, carrying sympathetic fibers.
  • This nerve travels through the pterygoid canal and ends in the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • While it is an important neural structure in the vicinity, it doesn't directly overlay the sphenoidal sinus floor but is rather related to the lateral and posterior aspects of the sphenoidal sinus within the deeper parts of the skull base.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 220

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a severe headache, double vision, and recent onset of facial weakness on the right side. His mother mentions that he has had a persistent ear infection for several weeks, which was initially treated with antibiotics without significant improvement. On examination, the boy has difficulty abducting his right eye, and there is noticeable weakness in the muscles of facial expression on the same side. Based on the clinical presentation and the history of a chronic ear infection, which cranial nerves are most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VI & VII

 

Option B:

 

Gradenigo's triad is characterized by -

A) 5th Cranial Nerve Involvement: Retro-orbital Pain, Paraesthesia over Face,

B) 6th Cranial Nerve Involvement: Diplopa  

C) Persistent Ear Discharge 

 

 

 

  • However, facial nerve (VII) involvement can also occur, presenting as facial weakness or paralysis on the affected side, which can be mistaken for involvement of the trigeminal nerve in terms of sensory loss or pain.

  • In this case, the boy's inability to abduct his right eye indicates involvement of the sixth cranial nerve (VI), and the facial weakness indicates involvement of the seventh cranial nerve (VII). Without any involvement of cranial nerve V.

  • This constellation of symptoms, along with the history of a persistent ear infection, supports a diagnosis of Gradenigo's syndrome.

  • The involvement of cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) in addition to VI (abducens nerve) rather than cranial nerve V (trigeminal nerve) in this case points to a more extensive spread of infection or inflammation from the ear (petrous apex), potentially affecting adjacent cranial nerves within the confined space of the temporal bone.

  •  Hence the answer is cranial nerve VI & VII

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: V & VI: This option includes the trigeminal nerve (CN V), which is involved in Gradenigo's syndrome through its ophthalmic division causing facial pain, and the abducens nerve (CN VI), which causes lateral rectus muscle palsy leading to double vision. This pairing partially matches the classic presentation of Gradenigo's syndrome.

 

Option C: VII & VIII: This option pairs the facial nerve (CN VII) and the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Neither of these nerves is primarily involved in Gradenigo's syndrome. While middle ear infections can potentially affect the facial nerve due to its proximity, this is not a characteristic feature of Gradenigo's syndrome, and CN VIII involvement would be unrelated.

 

Option D: IX & X: This option involves the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and the vagus nerve (CN X), neither of which is involved in Gradenigo's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • VI & VII: This option includes the abducens nerve (CN VI) and the facial nerve (CN VII). While CN VI involvement is consistent with Gradenigo's syndrome, CN VII is not typically associated with this condition. Gradenigo's syndrome primarily involves the trigeminal nerve (for the facial pain component) rather than the facial nerve.

  • Gradenigo syndrome is seen in infection of the petrous part of temporal bone. It presents a triad of symptoms which include -VII nerve palsy, VI nerve palsy and otitis media.

  • The VI nerve passes through the dorelloâ€™s canal which lies below the petrosphenoid Ligament at the apex of the petrous part of temporal bone.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 366

questions.text: Inferior Thyroid Artery is a Branch of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyrocervical Trunk

 

Option A: The thyrocervical trunk arises from the first part of subclavian artery and gives rise to inferior thyroid artery, suprascapular artery and transverse cervical artery.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Costo cervical trunk â€“ arises from the 2nd part of subclavian artery and gives rise to superior intercostal and deep cervical artery.

 

Option C: Internal carotid artery is one of terminal branch of common carotid artery at the level of C3-C4

 

Option D: External carotid artery gives rise to eight branches in the neck. Its terminal branches are the superficial temporal artery and maxillary artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior thyroid artery is indeed a branch of the thyrocervical trunk.

  • The thyrocervical trunk is a major branch of the subclavian artery, and it gives rise to several important arteries that supply the neck, upper chest, and shoulder area.

  • The inferior thyroid artery specifically supplies blood to the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, and surrounding structures in the neck.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 338

questions.text: Oral diaphragm is formed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mylohyoid

 

Option A: The mylohyoid muscle is part of the oral diaphragm. It forms the muscular floor of the mouth and helps support the tongue, allowing for various functions such as swallowing and speech. It is an important component of the oral diaphragm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Genioglossus arises from the superior genial tubercles of mandible and form the bulk of tongue inserting into it from root to its apex. The genioglossus is responsible for protruding and retracting the tongue. While it plays a crucial role in tongue movement and speech, it is not part of the oral diaphragm.

 

Option C: Hyoglossus muscles divides the lingual artery into three parts. The hyoglossus is involved in tongue movement. It assists in depressing and retracting the tongue. Like the genioglossus, it is not part of the oral diaphragm.

 

Option D: The buccinator muscle is located in the cheek and plays a role in compressing the cheeks against the teeth, aiding in actions like blowing air and keeping food in the mouth. It is not part of the oral diaphragm. Buccinator is a muscle of the cheek innervated by facial nerve

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mylohyoid muscle originates from the mylohyoid line of mandible and inserts. The fibers slope downward and medially, posterior 1/4th fibres is inserted into body of hyoid bone and anterior 3/4th fibres interdigitate in a median fibrous raphe. The mylohyoid muscle of both sides form a gutter shaped floor of the mouth and support the weight of the tongue, hence called diaphragm a orris. It divides the submandibular gland into a superficial and deep part.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 176

questions.text: Which of the following is unpaired Dural Venous Sinus:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basilar Venous Plexus

 

Option C:

 

  • Basilar venous plexus is an unpaired dural venous sinus located along the clivus at the base of the skull, beneath the brainstem.

  • The basilar venous plexus connects with several other venous structures, including the cavernous sinuses laterally, the pontine veins, and the internal vertebral venous plexuses.

  • It plays a role in draining blood from the brainstem and the posterior part of the brain.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The cavernous sinuses are paired structures located on either side of the sella turcica, surrounding the pituitary gland. They receive blood from several veins, including the ophthalmic veins and the sphenoparietal sinus, and drain into the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses.

 

 

Option B: The sphenoparietal sinus is also typically a paired structure, running along the edge of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone. It drains blood from the surface of the brain into the cavernous sinus.

 

Option D: The petrosquamous sinus is less commonly described and is considered a minor dural venous sinus, not as well-known or consistently identified as the others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unpaired dural venous sinus -superior sagittal sinus, inferior sagittal sinus, straight sinus, occipital sinus, basilar venous plexus, anterior and posterior intercavernous sinus

  • Paired dural venous sinus â€“ transverse sinus, sigmoid sinus, superior and inferior petrosal sinus, cavernous sinus, middle meningeal veins, sphenoparietal sinus, petrosquamous sinus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 348

choices.text: CSF is produced in the lateral ventricles and flows through the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.
CSF is produced in the fourth ventricle and flows through the lateral ventricles into the third ventricle.
CSF is produced in the third ventricle and flows through the lateral ventricles into the fourth ventricle.
CSF is produced in the fourth ventricle and flows directly into the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: Intracranial cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulates through various spaces and pathways. Which of the following accurately describes the pathway of CSF circulation within the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CSF is produced in the lateral ventricles and flows through the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.

 

Option A) This statement is accurate. CSF is produced primarily in the choroid plexus of the lateral ventricles, then CSF reaches into 3 ventricle & then into 4th ventricle as mentioned in flow chart.

 

CSF Pathway is shown in the following images; 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Understanding the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is essential in clinical anatomy.

 

Option B) CSF is produced in the fourth ventricle and flows through the lateral ventricles into the third ventricle.

 

  • This statement is not accurate. The primary production of CSF occurs in the lateral ventricles, and the flow is in direction described above.

 

Option C) CSF is produced in the third ventricle and flows through the lateral ventricles into the fourth ventricle.

 

  • This is also not following the correct order of CSF flow.

 

Option D) CSF is produced in the fourth ventricle and flows directly into the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

 

  • This statement is not accurate. CSF does pass into the subarachnoid space, but it undergoes further circulation within the ventricular system before reaching this space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary pathway of CSF circulation within the central nervous system involves its production in the choroid plexus of the lateral ventricles, followed by flow through the lateral ventricles, entry into the third ventricle, and continuation into the fourth ventricle.

 

Ref: Grayâ€™s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, International Edition, Page no- 412

choices.text: External Laryngeal Nerve
Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve
Internal Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: Fish Bone Area Sensory Supply:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal Laryngeal Nerve

 

Option D: Piriform fossa or the fish bone area is situated over the lateral wall of laryngopharynx and its mucosa is innervated by internal laryngeal nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: External laryngeal nerve ELN is entirely motor and supplies cricothyroid muscle which is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

Option B: Glossopharyngeal nerve carries general sensation from pharynx, tonsils, fauces and posterior 1/3 tongue.

 

Option C: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid and is also sensory to mucosa of larynx below the level of vocal cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sensory supply to the piriform fossa primarily comes from the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). The internal laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords, including the piriform fossa.
  • The piriform fossa is a pear-shaped depression located on either side of the laryngeal inlet, between the aryepiglottic fold and the thyroid cartilage. It is an important anatomical region for swallowing, as it helps to direct food and liquids away from the airway and towards the esophagus. The sensory innervation provided by the internal laryngeal nerve is crucial for triggering the swallowing reflex and protecting the airway during ingestion.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 230

choices.text: Stenson's Duct opens into Vestibule of Mouth opposite Upper Third Molar
External Carotid Artery pierces the Posterior Border to enter the Gland
Majority of Lymph Nodes are embedded in Deep Lobe
Deep Lobe Abscess can extend into Parapharyngeal Space

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the left side of his face, fever, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. On examination, there is noticeable swelling and tenderness over the left parotid region, and trismus is present. Imaging studies reveal an abscess in the deep lobe of the left parotid gland with extension into the adjacent parapharyngeal space. The patient is started on intravenous antibiotics and is being evaluated for possible surgical drainage. In the context of this patient's presentation and the anatomical considerations of parotid gland abscesses, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deep Lobe Abscess can extend into Parapharyngeal Space

 

Option D:

 

  • The parotid gland is the largest of the salivary glands and has a complex relationship with surrounding structures in the face and neck.
  • The Deep Lobe of the parotid gland is anatomically positioned such that an abscess can extend into the parapharyngeal space, a potential space lateral to the pharynx.
  • This extension can lead to significant complications due to the spread of infection into deeper neck spaces, potentially affecting airway, vascular structures, and the spread of infection to other deep neck spaces.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stenson's duct opens into vestibule of mouth opposite upper second molar.

 

Option B: External carotid artery pierces the posteromedial surface to enter the gland.

 

Option C: The facio venous plane of Patey divides the gland into superficial and deep lobe. The parotid lymph nodes lie over the superficial surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parapharyngeal space is bounded posterolaterally by parotid gland hence spread of abscess from parotid gland into this space and its further spread can result in Ludwig’s angina.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 96

questions.text: During a Routine Physical Examination, a 45-Year-Old Woman is noted to have a palpable nodule on her thyroid gland. She reports no symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, and her thyroid function tests are within normal limits. Given the presence of the thyroid nodule, further evaluation including ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration is planned. In preparation for potential surgical intervention, the surgical team reviews the vascular anatomy of the thyroid gland, focusing on the venous drainage, to minimize the risk of intraoperative bleeding. Understanding the venous drainage of the thyroid gland is crucial for thyroidectomy procedures. Which of the following veins is responsible for draining the middle thyroid vein?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal Jugular Vein

 

Option C:

 

  • The middle thyroid vein typically drains directly into the internal jugular vein. It arises from the lateral aspect of the thyroid gland, collecting blood from the isthmus and lateral lobes of the thyroid.

  • Then, it courses laterally to drain into the internal jugular vein. Unlike the superior and inferior thyroid veins, the middle thyroid vein does not have a corresponding artery (there is no middle thyroid artery).

  • Its drainage into the internal jugular vein is an important aspect of the venous drainage of the thyroid gland and neck region.

  • The oblique jugular vein is not a standard anatomical term associated with thyroid venous drainage.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: External jugular vein is present over the roof of the posterior triangle of neck and drains into subclavian vein.

 

Option B: Anterior jugular vein runs near the anterior median line of neck and drains into external jugular vein.

 

Option D: Oblique jugular vein communicates internal jugular vein with the external jugular vein in the upper part of neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The superior thyroid vein, middle thyroid vein and vein of kocher if present drains into the internal jugular vein.

  • The inferior thyroid veins drain into left brachiocephalic vein.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 307

choices.text: Decreased Salivation from Submandibular Salivary Gland
Loss of Taste Sensation from Anterior 2/3 of Tongue
Decreased Saliva Secretion from Sublingual Gland
Decreased Taste Sensation from Soft Palate

questions.text: Injury to Chorda Tympani leads to all the following Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Taste Sensation from Soft Palate

 

Option D: Decreased taste sensation from the soft palate is typically due to dysfunction or injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). The glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue, including the taste buds located on the soft palate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chorda tympani nerve carries preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres for submandibular salivary gland and joins the lingual nerve in infratemporal fossa and is distributed through it. It is in the submandibular ganglion. The postganglionic fibres pass directly to the submandibular gland.

 

Option B: Chorda tympani nerve represents the pretrematic branch of first branchial arch and conveys taste sensation from anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Option C: Chorda tympani nerve carries preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres for sublingual salivary gland and relays in submandibular ganglion. The postganglionic fibres enter back into lingual nerve and distributed to sublingual salivary gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Taste fibres from soft palate pass via lesser palatine nerves, pterygopalatine ganglion      without interruption, nerve of pterygoid canal and greater petrosal nerve and terminate as peripheral process of pseudounipolar neurons in geniculate ganglion.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 398
